title: 2021 WorldTour team bikes and equipment | Who’s riding what?
content:
The 19 teams that make up this year’s men’s WorldTour are getting ready to do battle. But with early season races cancelled, there’s less opportunity to show off their new equipment, with appearances limited to pre-season training camps.

There’s been the usual sponsorship entries and exits, although that’s been amplified by the pandemic. Departing team sponsors have included Sunweb, NTT and McLaren, while Team CCC has disappeared completely. 

New sponsor names include Nippo, DSM and BikeExchange, while Intermarché-Wanty-Gobert Matériaux is promoted to the top tier of men’s cycling.

That’s enough about team sponsors, what about the bikes and components they’re riding? Once you get to the bottom of the article and have seen all of this year’s team bikes, you can vote for your favourite.

Conservative changes

Team Qhubeka Assos

Many teams have kept to their tried-and-tested setups from last year. That’s in part a reflection of the truncated and delayed 2020 season, which has led to a shorter off-season than usual and less time to make changes.

There’s been the usual swapping of bike and equipment sponsor between teams though, with Bianchi, Scott and Cervélo all changing sponsored teams between them.

Cor Vos/Cor Vos Fotopersburo-Video ENG/Cor Vos

Significantly, Giant doesn’t have a men’s WorldTour team in 2021, for the first time in years – it’s been on the pro cycling scene since 1997 with the Once team.

Most other bike brands have stuck with their previous team sponsorships, although BMC now joins Specialized in sponsoring two teams (AG2R Citroen and Qhubeka Assos for BMC; Bora-Hansgrohe and Deceuninck-QuickStep for Specialized).

With each team sponsorship requiring up to 70 bikes, it’s a substantial commitment.

Decenuick-Quickstep

The start of the new season doesn’t just see sponsors switch teams, of course. We’ll have to get used to some of the peloton’s most prominent riders aboard new bikes in 2021.

Chris Froome is among them. Having ridden a Pinarello Dogma for more than a decade at Sky/Ineos, the four-time Tour de France winner will swap to a Factor bike in Israel Start-Up Nation colours this season.

Veloimages

Component swaps

Campagnolo now has four teams using its Super Record EPS drivetrain (AG2R Citroen, Cofidis, Lotto-Soudal and UAE Team Emirates), one up on 2020. There are two teams on SRAM (Trek-Segafredo and Movistar), while everyone else is using Shimano Dura-Ace Di2.

All teams are using electronic groupsets, but while Campag and SRAM both offer 12 speeds, Shimano continues to top out at 11 and there’s still no word of when a 12-speed Dura-Ace might appear, although we’ve speculated on what we’d like to see from the new Dura-Ace.

BMC

Campagnolo is well represented in wheel choices too, both in its own name and via Fulcrum, but again, Shimano dominates wheel sponsorship.

That’s a trend we’ve seen in recent years; groupset brands tying teams into deals with its wheel and component sub-brands.

BMC

As a result, Movistar are on Zipp wheels (owned by SRAM) and many teams are also running components and/or wheels from Shimano’s Pro brand. There’s a new entrant among wheel suppliers with British wheel brand Hunt linking up with Qhubeka Assos.

Power meters are a mixed medley with Shimano again dominating, but other brands like Rotor and Power2Max also getting a look-in. The original power meter specialist SRM continues to provide power measurement to three teams in Cofidis, Lotto-Soudal and UAE Team Emirates.

As for tyres, the usual big-name brands have a grip on team sponsorships, with Continental supplying five teams, while Vittoria and Pirelli both have multiple tie-ins. Goodyear, Wolfpack, Michael and Maxxis all have a team each.

Disc brakes take over

Pinarello

It’s only a few years since road disc brakes were anathema to the pros, with protests and a storm of social media moans. You don’t need us to tell you, however, that disc brakes have steadily taken over, both in the pro peloton and in bike shops. 

Last year, both Ineos Grenadiers and UAE Team Emirates were still exclusively on rim brake bikes, but this year the latter looks to have switched to disc brakes on its Colnagos. 

With the Pinarello Dogma F12 available both with both discs and rim brakes, and many of Pinarello’s other bikes disc brake only, is it just a matter of time until Ineos Grenadiers make the switch?

Charly Lopez

Who’s riding what?

2021 WorldTour bikes

AG2R Citroen Team

  • Framesets: BMC Teammachine SLR / Timemachine Road / Timemachine (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Campagnolo Super Record EPS
  • Wheels: Campagnolo Bora WTO / WTO Ultra
  • Components: BMC integrated bars
  • Pedals: Look Kéo Blade
  • Power meter: Power2Max
  • Tyres: Pirelli P Zero 
  • Other: Fizik saddles, Fizik bar tape, Elite bottle cages, Wahoo Elemnt Roam computers

Citroen joins as co-sponsor for the team this year and there’s a change of bikes to BMC and the new Teammachine launched last summer. 

After one year with Shimano providing the drivetrain, it’s back on Campagnolo, with the Super Record EPS groupset and Bora WTO aero wheelset.

Astana-Premier Tech

Tim de Waele / Getty Images

  • Framesets: Wilier Triestina Zero SLR / Wilier Filante / Turbine (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Corima
  • Components: Wilier integrated handlebars
  • Pedals: Look Kéo Blade
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Tyres: Wolfpack
  • Other: Prologo saddles, Tacx bottle cages, Prologo handlebar tape, CeramicSpeed jockey wheels

Astana will ride Wilier bikes again in 2021, with the team continuing its run on the Italian bike maker’s Zero SLR, the new aero/lightweight Filante and the Turbine time trial bike. 

Other kit choices remain the same too, with Shimano Dura-Ace drivetrains and the team’s wheels supplied by French brand Corima.

Bahrain Victorious

  • Framesets: Merida Scultura Disc / Reacto Disc / Warp TT
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Vision Metron
  • Components: FSA / Vision K-Force / Metron 5D, 6D handlebars and stems, FSA seatpost (Scultura only)
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Continental Competition Pro Ltd
  • Other: Prologo saddles, Elite bottle cages

Another team with a new name, following McLaren’s decision to leave pro cycling sponsorship after one season, Bahrain Victorious is sticking with the same bike and component sponsors as in 2020. 

So the team will continue to ride Merida’s bikes, with the latest generation Reacto Disc aero bike and the Scultura Disc. FSA and its Vision brand continue to be big component suppliers, providing cockpit and wheels to the team.

Bora-Hansgrohe

Bora-Hansgrohe

  • Framesets: Specialized S-Works Tarmac SL7 / Roubaix / Shiv TT
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Roval
  • Components: Pro handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Specialized S-Works Turbo / Turbo Cotton / Rapid Air
  • Other: Specialized saddles, Wahoo Elemnt Bolt GPS computers

It’s business as usual for Bora-Hansgrohe, with Specialized again its major equipment supplier.

That, of course, includes the team’s bikes, with the new Tarmac SL7, launched in the middle of last year, replacing the Tarmac SL6 and the Venge in one go, while the Roubaix is available for races over the cobbles. 

Specialized also handles saddle and tyres for the team, which uses wheels from Spesh’s Roval sub-brand. Groupset components come from Shimano, with a sprinkling of parts from the Japanese firm’s Pro sub-brand.

Cofidis

Cofidis

  • Framesets: De Rosa Merak / TT-03
  • Drivetrain: Campagnolo Super Record EPS
  • Wheels: Fulcrum Speed
  • Components: FSA/Vision ACR handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Look Kéo
  • Power meter: SRM Campagnolo
  • Tyres: Michelin Power
  • Other: Selle Italia saddles, Elite Cannibal XC bottle cages

Cofidis’s De Rosa Merak bike gets a new red and black colour scheme for 2021, but otherwise kit options remain the same as last year. 

That includes the Campag Super Record EPS drivetrain and SRM power meter, as well as the Fulcrum Speed wheelsets and Selle Italia saddles. Cofidis is the only team on Michelin tyres. 

Deceuninck-QuickStep

  • Framesets: Specialized S-Works Tarmac SL7 / Roubaix / Shiv TT
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Roval
  • Components: Pro handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Tyres: Specialized S-Works Turbo / Turbo Cotton / Rapid Air
  • Other: Specialized saddles, Wahoo Elemnt Bolt GPS computers

Like Bora-Hansgrohe, Deceuninck-QuickStep keeps to the tried-and-tested Specialized theme for 2021, with the Tarmac SL7 its main ride.

That will be the bike used by the returned Mark Cavendish, who previously found so much success on the now-defunct Venge. The Roubaix may be swapped in as an option for the cobbled classics and the Shiv TT is on hand for time trials.

Other Specialized kit includes the saddles, while the team will use the Wahoo Elemnt Bolt computer and the Tickr heart rate monitor. Like Bora-Hansgrohe, the team will use Shimano groupsets and Pro bars and stems.

EF Education-Nippo

  • Framesets: Cannondale SuperSix EVO / SystemSix / SuperSlice (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2, Cannondale HollowGram SiSL2 cranks with FSA chainrings
  • Wheels: Vision Metron 40SL, Vision Metron 50SL
  • Components: FSA/Vision K-Force / Metron 5D, 6D
  • Pedals: Speedplay Zero
  • Power meter: Power2Max NG and NGeco HollowGram power meter
  • Tyres: Vittoria Corsa
  • Other: Prologo saddles, FSA chainrings, Tacx bottle cages, Garmin GPS computers

EF Education-Nippo will continue on Cannondale bikes for 2021, with the bike maker signing up to equip the team through to 2023, a nine-year stretch. 

As in 2020, the team will have a mixed calendar including gravel and mountain bike events as well as road, so more of Cannondale’s range will be on show, not just its road bikes. 

The black and pink colour scheme continues for 2021, but like the Palace Skateboards collaboration in 2020, expect some more eye-popping paintwork specials during the season.

Groupama-FDJ

Justin Setterfield / Getty Images

  • Framesets: Lapierre Xelius SL Disc / Aircode SL / Aérostorm (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Shimano Dura-Ace / PRO
  • Components: Pro handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Tyres: Continental Competition Pro Ltd
  • Other: Prologo saddles, Elite bottle cages

Groupama-FDJ will be riding Lapierre bikes again in 2021, with the Xelius SL Disc and Aircode SL its options for road stages. 

Components are dominated by Shimano with a Dura-Ace Di2 groupset and a mix of wheels from Shimano and Pro, which also supplies the cockpit for the team’s bikes.

Ineos Grenadiers

Pinarello

  • Framesets: Pinarello Dogma F12 / Dogma K10 / Bolide TT
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Shimano Dura-Ace / Pro
  • Components: MOST handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Tyres: Continental Competition Pro Ltd
  • Other: Fizik saddles, Elite bottle cages

The partnership with Pinarello continues for Ineos Grenadiers – the team has been riding the Dogma in its different incarnations since 2009, and the latest Dogma F12 continues into 2021. 

It’s still the last redoubt of rim brakes in the WorldTour ranks, although there’s a disc brake F12 available too. Will we see the team finally going disc this year?

Otherwise, it’s business as usual for Ineos, with Shimano groupsets, Continental tyres and Fizik saddles.

Intermarché-Wanty-Gobert Matériaux

David Stockman / Getty Images

  • Framesets: Cube Litening C:68X / Aerium TT
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2
  • Wheels: Newmen
  • Components: Cube integrated bar/stem
  • Pedals: Look Kéo
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Continental Competition Pro Ltd
  • Other: Prologo saddles, Elite cages, Bryton computers

Stepping up to WorldTour level for the first time this season and with a new title sponsor, Belgium team Intermarché-Wanty-Gobert Matériaux will be riding Cube bikes, including the Litening C:68X. 

Groupset components come from Shimano, who will provide the Dura-Ace Di2 drivetrain, while the team will roll on Newmen wheels with Continental tyres.

The colour scheme is toned down to a more muted black with fluoro highlights, a change from the previous riot of blue and yellow.

Israel Start-Up Nation

Toni Vilches

  • Framesets: Factor Ostro VAM / O2 VAM / One / Slick (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Black Inc 30 / 45 / 60
  • Components: Black Inc one piece bar/stem
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: 4iiii Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Maxxis High Road
  • Other: Selle Italia saddles, CeramicSpeed bottom brackets and pulley wheels, Elite bottle cages, Hammerhead Karoo 2 computers, Swissstop brake pads

Chris Froome’s new home continues on Factor bikes this year, including the Ostro lightweight/aero bike and the lightweight O2 VAM launched in 2020, with components from Factor’s Black Inc brand. 

The Shimano drivetrains are supplemented by shiny, low-friction CeramicSpeed jockey wheels and bottom bracket bearings, plus Swissstop brake pads. Tyres come from Maxxis and it’s the only team using the Hammerhead Karoo 2 cycling computer.

Jumbo-Visma

  • Framesets: Cervélo R5 Disc / S5 Disc / Caledonia / P5 (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Components: Cervélo handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Vittoria
  • Other: Fizik saddles, Tacx bottle cages, Garmin computers

One of the merry-go-round of bike sponsor changes for 2021, Jumbo-Visma swaps from long-time provider Bianchi to Cervélo, with a new yellow and black colour scheme to match its kit. It’s certainly a better match than Bianchi’s celeste.

There’s a range of bikes available including the lightweight R5, aero S5 and the new Cervélo Caledonia, a specialist bike for the cobbles, with extra-wide clearances. 

Lotto Soudal

Ridley

  • Framesets: Ridley Noah Fast Disc / Helium SLX Disc / Dean Fast (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Campagnolo Super Record EPS
  • Wheels: Campagnolo Bora 35 Disc / 50 Disc
  • Components: Deda Handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Look Kéo
  • Power meter: SRM Campagnolo
  • Tyres: Vittoria Corsa / Corsa Speed
  • Other: Selle Italia saddles, Tacx bottle cages, Garmin computers

Lotto Soudal keeps things Belgian and sticks with its long-time bike sponsor Ridley again this year, with the Noah Fast Disc its aero bike and the Helium SLX providing extra lift for hilly stages.

The team says the Helium SLX remains the most popular bike with its riders, although its sprinters go for the Noah Fast. It’s offered them custom paintwork for this season.

It’s one of the four teams on Campagnolo this year, running Super Record EPS and Bora wheels.

Movistar Team

Movistar

  • Framesets: Canyon Ultimate CF SLX / Aeroad CFR / Speedmax CF SLX (TT)
  • Drivetrain: SRAM Red eTap AXS
  • Wheels: Zipp
  • Components: Canyon handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Look Kéo
  • Power meter: SRAM Red AXS
  • Tyres: Continental Competition Pro Ltd
  • Other: Fizik saddles, Canyon bottle cages, Garmin computers, Lizard Skins bar tape

Canyon sponsors Movistar again this season, with the team rolling on its Ultimate all-rounder and the new Canyon Aeroad CFR, along with the Speedmax TT bike. 

It’s one of two teams on SRAM Red eTap AXS and the only one on Zipp wheels this year.

Team BikeExchange

  • Framesets: Bianchi Specialissima Disc / Oltre XR4 Disc / Aquila (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2 
  • Wheels: Shimano Dura-Ace C40 / C60
  • Components: Vision bars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Pirelli P Zero
  • Other: Fizik saddles, Tacx bottle cages

Team BikeExchange has, well, exchanged bikes this year. It’s now on Bianchi bikes, with the celeste machines taking over from long-time bike provider Scott. 

It’s got Bianchi’s latest Specialissima to play with – the lightweight bike is now more aero, stiffer and disc brake only.

There’s still the aero Oltre XR4. That bike has a rim brake option, although it doesn’t look as if the team will be using it. Other kit comes from Shimano and the cockpit is from FSA’s Vision brand.

Team DSM

Team DSM

  • Framesets: Scott Addict RC / Foil RC / Plasma 5 (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2
  • Wheels: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Components: Syncros handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Tyres: Vittoria
  • Other: Pro saddles, Elite bottle cages, Wahoo computers

Team DSM, the new sponsor taking over from Sunweb, also gets a bike swap to Scott this year. The main bike for road stages will be the aero/lightweight Addict RC, with its integrated bar/stem coming from Scott’s Syncros component brand.

It’s another team running Shimano components, including wheels, as well as the Dura-Ace Di2 drivetrain.

Team Qhubeka Assos

Team Qhubeka Assos

  • Framesets: BMC Teammachine SLR / Timemachine Road / Timemachine (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Shimano Dura-Ace Di2, Rotor chainsets
  • Wheels: Hunt Bike Wheels Limitless
  • Components: BMC integrated bars
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace
  • Power meter: Rotor Aldhu
  • Tyres: Goodyear Eagle
  • Other: Selle Italia saddles, CeramicSpeed jockey wheels, Tacx bottle cages

Team Qhubeka Assos will continue on the BMC bikes ridden by its predecessor, NTT Pro Cycling, with the Teammachine the go-to race steed. 

But there are component changes, with the team using wheels from UK brand Hunt and Rotor’s Aldhu power meter, along with Goodyear Eagle tyres.

Like Israel Start-Up Nation, it’s using CeramicSpeed’s oversized jockey wheels to give its drivetrains a low-friction boost. 

Trek-Segafredo

Luc Claessen / Getty Images

  • Framesets: Trek Émonda SLR / Madone SLR / Speed Concept (TT)
  • Drivetrain: SRAM Red eTap AXS
  • Wheels: Bontrager Aeolus
  • Components: Bontrager handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Shimano Dura-Ace 
  • Power meter: SRAM Red AXS
  • Tyres: Pirelli
  • Other: Bontrager saddles

With Trek as co-title sponsor, Trek-Segafredo are continuing on the same bikes as last year, along with wheels and components from Trek’s Bontrager brand.

Bikes available are the Émonda SLR all-rounder, given an update in 2020 to become more aero, and Madone SLR aero bike, which in turn has become lighter.

Along with Movistar, it’s one of two teams running SRAM eTap AXS 12-speed wireless groupsets. It’s also on Pirelli tyres mounted to deep-section Bontrager carbon wheels; the tyre maker has increased its presence in the pro peloton significantly in the last couple of years.

UAE Team Emirates

UAE Team Emirates / Photo Fizza

  • Framesets: Colnago V3Rs / Concept / C64 / K.one (TT)
  • Drivetrain: Campagnolo Super Record EPS
  • Wheels: Campagnolo Bora
  • Components: Deda handlebars and stems
  • Pedals: Look Kéo
  • Power meter: SRM
  • Tyres: Vittoria Corsa / Corsa Speed
  • Other: Prologo saddles, Elite bottle cages, SRM computers

Colnago renews its successful link with UAE Team Emirates this year, with the V3Rs all-rounder featuring.

The team rode 2020 on rim brakes, but the publicity shot for this year’s team shows Tour de France winner Tadej Pogačar holding a disc brake bike and there’s not a rim brake bike in sight on the team’s Facebook page. 

It looks as if UAE Team Emirates will finally be swapping to Campagnolo’s disc brake groupset in 2021, leaving only Ineos Grenadiers on rim brakes.

The wheels also come from Campagnolo’s Bora line-up, while the team’s cockpit is supplied by Deda and an SRM power meter completes the bulk of the build.

Vote for your favourite 2021 WorldTour team bike
author: Paul Norman
